channel.title: Combined Politepol Feed
channel.description: Merged feed from multiple Politepol sources

item.title: In Graphics | Diwali on Unesco’s heritage list: What else has achieved global recognition from India?
Was the ‘Star of Bethlehem’ that led to baby Jesus a comet? Here’s what a Nasa scientist found
Why Pakistan's idea of a South Asia bloc without India is bound to fail
Why have fresh protests gripped Adiala Jail in Pakistan over Imran Khan?
In Graphics | What is Blue Notice issued against Luthra bros in Thailand over Goa nightclub fire?
How many energy drinks are too many? A man suffered a stroke after 8
Trump’s threat of new tariffs on Indian rice deepens trade standoff
item.description: A major breakthrough should not be expected in the immediate future, as the new tariff threats create a difficult environment for compromise.

item.title: Rushdie’s duplicity: How a victim of ‘Islamist knife’ finds Hindu nationalism an easy target
item.description: Salman Rushdie invokes the ghost of ‘Hindu nationalism’ even when Islamists continue to aim at his life. Maybe his ‘rebellion’ is dead, and only the fear survives

item.title: From protests to polls: Nepal’s March 5 vote tests a new political era
item.description: With so many parties running, the election could also end without a clear winner, creating more uncertainty

item.title: How Jaishankar’s Pakistan diagnosis is accurate, and why India must build on it
item.description: The External Affairs Minister is correct in categorically stating that India should never seek to hyphenate itself with Pakistan–now India is far ahead of Pakistan

item.title: A hemisphere-first strategy: Ten ways America has redrawn its global role in the new NSS
item.description: The new National Security Strategy seeks to reshape America’s position within the global order, compressing global obligations while expanding the instruments of coercive economic statecraft.

item.title: Pakistan’s overseas crackdown: A human rights test America can’t ignore
item.description: Over recent years, Pakistani journalists, activists and commentators living abroad have described a troubling pattern: speak critically of Pakistan’s military or political establishment, and the retaliation begins.
